commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Extremely well-liked?  (8)(6)
2. Exchanges blows?  (3)(6)
3. Building that shouldn't have running water?  (3)(6)
4. Where idols go head-to-head  (5)
5. Paired chips with dips?  (6)


INTERNET FAMOUS
AIR KISSES
ICE PALACE
TOTEM
RHYMED
Nice easy start to the week.  Under my average time but nowhere near a personal best.
4 minutes under my average. Enjoyed it very much but some might argue that it has a lot of naticks for a Monday. Effete was new to me.
Thanks, Lynn Lempel, for this jaunty little Monday puzzle. Finishing it completes my 1-year streak!

"You thought I was planning to go to the airport?"
"Oh, yeah, that's plane to see."

("Actually, I'm just winging it.")
21-Across is simply wrong.  The acting started years earlier.

Thanks for yet another delightful Monday, Lynn Lempel!

N.B. This is NYT XWP #104 for Ms. Lempel, and her 75th Monday. She made her debut in 1979.
Another fun puzzle! Loved it. Enjoyed the theme. Just full of good stuff! Thanks, Lynn. Happy Monday, y‚Äôall!!
Anyone else have deja vu on this one?

I hope there are no STOWAWAYS aboard. 

Remember the golden age of aviation when passengers wore CHIC ATTIRE to travel? Those were the good OLD days. 

Worried about in-flight ENNUI? Bring along some reading material to PERUSE, or maybe you can watch a KEANU movie. Hopefully you will NOD off. 

Take heart, the flight will have been WORTH it when you ARRIVE in ROME.
Very enjoyable puzzle! Thank you Lynn Lempel , I always love your puzzles, though admittedly I didn't get the theme until I read Sam's  commentary! Oh well c'est la vie!

Filial... when ever I see this word, I am thankful I don't live in a Filial State and like to point out to others this danger:
Filial Law & Long Term Care
Filial responsibility laws are state statutes in about 30 U.S. states that can legally obligate adult children to financially support their indigent parents, often for nursing home or long-term care costs, stemming from old English Poor Laws. While rarely enforced for daily living, they become relevant when parents need public assistance (like Medicaid), triggering potential lawsuits by care providers or states against children for unpaid bills, especially if parents transferred assets or children signed agreements.

Lots of echoes of Emily Dickinson's "I heard a fly buzz when I died" here. Tempted to write a parody using some of the entries, I reread the poem and was so moved by it that it would have seemed a desecration to attempt such a thing. 

And there are other, ancillary entries in the puzzle that speak to the modern experience of flying, the KNEE whose EDGE digs into your back from the fellow behind you, the ORDERS to deboard because your ATTIRE, which you thought CHIC, was deemed inappropriate by the flight attendant because the HEM was a little high and didn't HIDE enough. As you walked back up the aisle all EYES were upon you and you felt like curling up in a FETAL position from sheer embarrassment. Even the PATROL MAN LEERED at you. Maybe you can hide in the bathroom, like STOWAWAYS of OLD. Or maybe if you seek COUNSEL you can SIOUX the airline and recover some of your ASSETS. And blimey, the ennui of travel these days! Will you ever arrive in Rome?

I heard a Fly buzz - when I died -
The Stillness in the Room
Was like the Stillness in the Air -
Between the Heaves of Storm -

The Eyes around - had wrung them dry -
And Breaths were gathering firm
For that last Onset - when the King
Be witnessed - in the Room -

I willed my Keepsakes - Signed away
What portion of me be
Assignable - and then it was
There interposed a Fly -

With Blue - uncertain - stumbling Buzz -
Between the light - and me -
And then the Windows failed - and then
I could not see to see -
Almost too easy....
Nice puzzle. Fill was easy, and due to my inexperience of traveling, I didn't get what the theme meant until I came here.  Whoops! Anyways, happy new year! :)

Nice puzzle! A good one for my ‚Äúacross clues only‚Äù challenge. I finished in 10:42 without looking at any down clues. A good use of insomnia. Next up: counting sheep without looking at any of the downy ones, only cross-breeds‚Ä¶

Curious to know if anyone else found that 41A triggered a recollection of an entirely different dueling pair.  I‚Äôm thinking of the old TV series, ‚ÄúPerry Mason‚Äù from the ‚Äò50s and ‚Äò60s. Starring Raymond BURR as defence attorney, Perry Mason, and Willian Talman as his nemesis, district attorney, HAMILTON Burger.
My fastest solve on record!

My resolution? 
Why yes. More travel down those side roads . . .

Gonna HIDE my pencil, solve in ink tonight
Gonna grab that gold star delight
My PENNAME it ain't real but "When it's right, it's right"
Why DWELL on a BYLINE in a solving fight?
Let's TAKEOFFROMWORK we NEED a holiday
And hope no dang oreos TOUCHDOWN in the grid today!

Thinkin' of ADOBO woke my appetite
Lookin' forward to a little spicy food tonight
Sendin' ORDERS on the phone made the grub ARRIVE
But the the buzz of STOWAWAYS got this girl to fightin!

FLYSWATTER in flight
WOE to bugs tonight
WO O O O OH OH OH OH OH 
WOE to bugs tonight!

Started out this puzzle' feelin' so polite
I always thought an IGLOO would be colder than a TENT inside
But that bug a-waitin' in my TBONE, it just aint right
Like a BOARDROOM of ATONAL fleas and mites!

FLYSWATTER in flight
WOE to bugs tonight
WO O O O OH OH OH OH OH 
WOE to bugs tonight!

Be waitin' for me, COUNSEL, when I come around
We can SIOUX the cook, send the PATROLMAN 'round!

Fun one! And I set a new personal best of 5 minutes flat. But wait, I am not a person who shares times, why do I share my time today!? 

Well, that's because I only achieved it after accidentally resetting my completed puzzle that took a few minutes longer than five. Proving what I've known all along, that even knowing all the answers, there's no way I could type fast enough or typo free enough to get the really short times that people report. 

I have no issues with that at all, but what always amazes me is just the ability the speedy solvers have to fill in so fast without fat fingering it. Anyhow, now I have a new personal best that I can probably never beat even if I really wanted to. Whoohoo! Freedom!!

Even on the first go through, it almost completely filled in on its own from the acrosses, except that at 9A, I put in idea before coming back and changing it to HALO. I rather like my, err, idea, but even if it could manage to be a good clue it wouldn't be a Monday clue.

Very pleasant puzzle with a nice theme. Even though claustrophobic me is not a fan of flying, it makes me doubly want to be somewhere Caribbean warm, colorful, and sunny again...  

Oh, dear. Unwarranted, the thought of my beloved Caribbean just made me sad...  Okay, me, this is a puzzle forum, moving on!
The 11/5/1996 puzzle got it wrong when HAITI was clued as Port-au-Prince's *island*.
Just a quick note: Mr. T wasn't a wrestler-turned-actor, he was an actor-turned-wrestler.
This was the puzzle that completed my 5 year Monday streak! I posted a comment for my 1 year streak as I was at the start of medical school and I'm now on my final placement in Vanuatu :)

Thank you for the puzzle! I enjoyed it :) A quick heads up, on history, Crazy Horse was a member of the Lakota Nation. Indigenous people do not use the word ‚ÄúSioux‚Äù as it is insulting. Settlers adopted the name when a rival nation was asked what they were called.

What a fun way to start the week - a real short and sweet one that epitomises the best of a Monday puzzle! It also gave me a personal best of under 9 minutes - which was a great relief after disastrous attempts at Wordle and Connections today. My first morning back at work after the Christmas break definitely needed this win!

esthetically pleasing theme which, par for a monday, is entirely unnecessary for the solve.

andrzej et al will be unimpressed.
Not being very bright I was confused by the theme and revealer ü§™

Always appreciate one from "the queen of the Mondays", Lynn Lempel. This is her 75th Monday puzzle, out of 104 total. All but 10 of her puzzles have been early-week. She has a knack for striking a good balance for Monday puzzles, with them being neither too difficult nor too easy, and this one was a typically excellent puzzle.

Thanks, Lynn!

After the solve the elegance of the theme was evident. Superb. 

Being a Monday the solving was too quick to need the theme. 

Thanks for a great first Monday puzzle of the year.
Clever and breezy.  Thank you Ms. Lempel.
Great Monday puzzle! Very nice theme, took me 3 times to read the sequence b4 it caught, aha!

Once again I‚Äôm asking the editors to discover what an igloo actually is, if they‚Äôre going to use it as regular glue. 

An igloo is a temporary shelter used when you‚Äôre out hunting. It‚Äôs basically a camping tent. Nobody lives in igloos and they aren‚Äôt ‚Äúhomes.‚Äù 

As an Inuk I don‚Äôt mind igloos being used as clues at all, but I wish they weren‚Äôt always used for this vaguely racist picture where Inuit don‚Äôt have houses.

I have to comment on 50 down, Tbone, clued as "Steak similar to a porterhouse".  That is like cluing airplane as an aircraft similar to a jet.  All jets are airplanes, but not all airplanes are jets.  Just like all porterhouse steaks are Tbones, but not all Tbones are portehouses.  Just sayin'.
An elegant Monday, though I needed Sam to explain the theme to me.

I hate to be picky...but I will.  The adobo that I happoen to be most familiar with--that used in Filipino cooking--does not have chili peppers at all.  Yes, I recognize that some adobos do, but a qualifier here, such "sometimes" or even "often" would recognize that the ingredients for this particular item can and do vary enormously.

I‚Äôve been doing a rewatch of Mad Men, and in the episode I just saw, Bert Cooper was doing the NYT crossword. He stopped and asked aloud, ‚ÄúWhat is a 3-letter word for a flightless bird?‚Äù 

A wink from the writing staff, I presume. Some things never change‚Ä¶
Not too bad today, though for some reason I got stuck on ROSA not realizing it was referring to Rosa parks' last name and wondering what in the world type of national park would end in OSA...

TIL that ‚Äúparer‚Äù is the occasional pen name for a pencil sharpener (in Ireland at least, according to Wikipedia).

After touch down, remember: TIS better to have luggage lost, than never to have luggage at all.

Mr. T wrestled in high school, so technically 21A is correct, but his career trajectory went as follows: bodyguard, bouncer (he prefers the title doorman) featured in "America's Toughest Bouncer" (note: his bodyguarding and bouncing careers overlapped), movie star ("Rocky III"), TV star ("The A Team"), and only then wrestler. Also, he only wrestled professionally one time, as I recall--the main event of Wrestlemenia I. He appeared in Wrestlemania II as well, but this time as a boxer.

Very nice. Almost without help, but didn't know Patriot games clue. I looked up MRT afterwards, thinking it was an unknown to me wrestler (I don't know any wrestlers) and oh no! it was Mr T that my kids watched years ago.

Nice one.


Go Bills.
A perfectly lovely Monday puzzle. Cute theme, easy enough for beginners, and no Star Wars of sports clues! Thanks, Lynn, as always.
A near perfect Monday puzzle! Theme was cute if a little unnecessary, IMO, but if it helped someone solve, then all the better. Happy Monday!

I had no idea so many were familiar with the career arc of MR T. 

Congrats to Ms Lempel on her 75th Monday.

A flight of fancy.

There's no place like dome, Sam.

So, this puzzle of Ms. Lempel's is a flight of fantasy?  
Nice.
(Except that TAKE OFF is two words as clued and entered/read, which is a slight blemish.)

Since I solve bottom to top, my first two entries designated in the Reveal clue (TOUCHDOWN and FLY) would seem to be "scoring accomplishments" or some such, even if "Gridiron" was a poor fit.  Any time we get suckered into guessing like that, we end up getting SWATTed down.  
Nice sequence, clever puzzle.

P.S.  I don't remember EWAN McGregor in the movie...and we've never watched the TV spin-off.  Should we?

Nice Monday puzzle. Fairly smooth solve, but I didn't tumble to the theme until I was almost done. That's always a nice touch. Puzzle find today - a Tuesday from October 22, 2019 by Saul Pink. This one was all in the clues; thought it was a cute theme. "Comedian who's make a good pyrotechnician?" GEORGEBURNS "Supermodel who'd make a good broker?" TYRABANKS "Activist who'd make a good valet?" ROSAPARKS "Rapper who'd make a good barber?" SEANCOMBS "Actor who'd make a good dry cleaner?" JEREMYIRONS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=10/22/2019&g=35&d=A I'm done. ....
I don't recall seeing @suejean in a while, but I miss a lot. Maybe she is on holiday? I hope all is well.

Speaking of Emily Dickinson, here's a great poem by Edna St. Vincent Millay. One of my favorites and perfect for making-resolution time: 

FEAST

  I drank at every vine. 
     The last was like the first. 
   I came upon no wine 
     So wonderful as thirst.  
   I gnawed at every root. 
     I ate of every plant. 
   I came upon no fruit 
     So wonderful as want.  
   Feed the grape and bean 
    To the vintner and monger; 
  I will lie down lean 
    With my thirst and my hunger.

Monday puzzles can be amusing, but I rarely expect to learn anything from them, because the clues and answers are geared to greater simplicity.

But, thanks to @Sam Corbin, today I learned that the words "EFFETE" and "FETAL" are etymologically related.  
The origin of "effete" has to do with being worn out from childbirth, and hence no longer fertile [ex + fetus = no longer childbearing].  
From there the word came to mean "no longer capable of effective action" as in "effete aristocracy" or "effete intellectuals".
And from there to our "overly refined" or "affected".

Interesting stuff!  Thanks, Sam!

Lovely Monday grid, Lynn Lempel -- thank you! 

Here's to safe travels for everyone, whether by land, sea or air~
Good job Lynn üëç

Good puzzle overall, but the revealer made zero sense to me until I read the column. Even now that I understand it, I still find it to be terrible and too weird for a Monday puzzle. The only thing it added to my solve was confusion. In my opinion, it‚Äôs the worst part of the puzzle and would be better off replaced by a non-revealer clue. Other than the revealer though, I did quite like this. I didn‚Äôt get everything right away, but the answers kept coming as I made passes through the puzzle. It‚Äôs rare for me to find one where I can maintain momentum like that.

PATROLMAN is sexist.  Lots of women officers have their beats.  Time to toss that term in the bin.  Officer works just fine for both. 

- Daughter of a fallen patrol woman.

Fun past couple of days.  Today:  A gem.  Yesterday: Brilliant construction and was fun trying to guess those "done wrong". 

But still plugging away on that Saturday Stumper!
I was one letter short of getting this from only the down clues. I didn't know how to spell adobo. I guess I should have known GOO was more likely than GAO. ü´§
Enjoyed flying the Friendly Skies of Lempel Airline...and a  smooth landing!!

Okay, so I recognize the Seattle skyline (column photo) from "Frasier" but is it the home of a dome? They demolished the Kingdome years ago, and the replacement arena has an open roof, from all the pictures I've seen. Oh, never mind, it's Toronto.
I have completed this puzzle,01/03/26 but it has not registered as solved; not the first time this glitch has occurred!
Shouldn‚Äôt 21 across be ‚Äúactor-turned-wrestler‚Äù not ‚Äúwrestler-turned-actor‚Äù
I especially enjoyed today's crossword. No complaints. Loved the overhead light clue! Cheers to the cruciverbalist for a job well done.

Mr. T was not a wrestler turned actor.  He was a bouncer/bodyguard turned actor who wrestled a couple times as a celebrity guest (after becoming famous as an actor) and then made sporadic wrestling-related appearances.

For the last few weeks I've been getting a warning in the Games App that I need to upgrade to newer version.  But it won't let me because my iPad is too old!  New Games App requires iOS 18.   I'm on 16.7, and can't upgrade, just because Apple says so.  They want me to buy a new one.

Now today I can't use Games App at all!!  I hate all this 'planned obsolesence!'  Yes, iPad is 7 years old, but it works just fine.  I can do everything on it I want to do -- except Games App.

I did find a work-around.  The NYTimes App has a Games link.  That one still works.  I don't like the crossword layout as well -- font is smaller for my old eyes.  And it doesn't have a link to Wordplay column.  I had to go to Sections and do search.  Nuisance....

I have a cross-stitched plaque my sister made me:  "Use it Up, Wear It Out, Make It Do, or Do Without"  and that's the way I live.

I drove to work today in a car that is 70 years old!  1956 T-bird my Dad bought new, and when I stop driving I have a son who will keep it running.

I work for a school district with about 2000 Chromebooks.  6 years ago Google decided Chromebooks should only work for 4 years -- no more system upgrades, even though they worked fine.  We had to replace them so we could still do the Calif standardized testing.  Los Angeles Unified had 80,000 useless Chromebooks!  I guess they all went in the landfill?  There was a big, big fuss, and the new ones we bought are good for 8 years, which is better, but still too short.
I enjoyed this puzzle and the football theme! It was a nice way to ease into the week, and I learned some new words (effete and filial).
Help! I use the iPad app for Games. It is telling me I have to upgrade to iOS 18, but that version is still in the Beta stage.
I can‚Äôt seem to access Wordplay for January 5.

If you're here because the link to Tuesday's Wordplay column is broken, close these comments and scroll all the way down to the bottom of today's column and you'll see a link to  Tuesday's column entitled Splendid Serve.
Crazy Horse was a member of the Oglala Lakota. The term used in Monday's crossword (7 Down) is a name given by white French settlers, not a Native name. Its use by the Times is disappointing.

My favorite encore clues from last week:

[Book reviewer, for short]
[Part of an underground network]


CPA
ROOT
@Kate Palmer -- It is original, and I loved it as well.  It was really hard to narrow my choices to five this week.

@John

For menthis was 50% over my Monday PB ü§∑üèΩ
@Megan effete is a common word for me, maybe because I‚Äôve always been an Oscar Wilde fan, but what else was natick? Everything seemed pretty straightforward to me.

Megan,
I understand one word was new to you, but a Natick is when two words cross, you know neither of them from the clue or with crosses, and you can't figure out the letter where the two words cross. Where did you encounter Naticks in this puzzle?

@Barry Ancona

I thought that Natick was more specifically usually used for crossings of obscure proper nouns? Not just clues that someone has trouble guessing. If I‚Äôm wrong in my understanding of it, then happy to stand corrected! I agree with your question though, as to where they were in this puzzle.

Kirsten,
The original was -- Rex Parker couldn't cross NCWYETH with NATICK. He subsequently broadened the term to the cross of two words (not just proper nouns) where "most solvers" would not be "expected to know" either one.

@Barry Ancona I would assume the closest thing to a Natick in this puzzle is EFFETE and FILIAL? Personally, I‚Äôve loved the word EFFETE for years, but I recently learned FILIAL from the Spelling Bee.

@Barry Ancona depending on your immersion/exposure to various cultures and the definition of ‚Äúexpected to know‚Äù the crossings: 

ERIC/BRICE 
TURK/KEANU/SIOUX 
AARON/ROME 
ROSA/MRT 

Could be regarded naticky. Personally I found the puzzle very straightforward and am somewhat surprised that there are comments about EFFETE herein. But one‚Äôs own experience doesn‚Äôt and shouldn‚Äôt rate the puzzle for others. 

Have a great solving year üòÄ

@Megan

Should we infer that you're too young to recall Spiro Agnew's attacks on the "EFFETE corps of impudent snobs"?
@Kate Palmer i know filial from learning about chinese culture, the term filial piety comes up over and over there.

ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ,
The cross of any two words could be a Natick for somebody, but I trust you agree "most solvers" should be able to handle your four examples.

Happy solving to you too!
@Barry Ancona absolutely agree.

@Jack McCullough,

That‚Äôs the first thing I think of when I see that word. Sounds like William Safire at work.

@Jack McCullough

Don't be a nattering nabob of negativity!
@Jim congrats!
@Jim Nice--quite the effete! (sorry--just a 60D to 42D)

@Jim,

Congratulations!! üéâüéàüçæ ü•Ç
@Jim Congratulations!
@Mike I was an early venture capital investor in an international air travel company, but I‚Äôve had to put some extra funds in. This is what we financiers call ‚Äúre-seeding airline‚Äù

@Mike

Another flight of fancy!.  You're always up in the air about something, you goose. Down, I say.
@Petrol Bahaha, brilliant.

@Mike
I believe you accidently tripped on the tarmac...
The acting started years earlier than the *professional* wrestling, but he wrestled in high school.
@Barry Ancona Huh.  I guess that's true, but I doubt it's what the constructor intended.

Adam,
I don't know who wrote the clue, and I don't know what the checkers knew about MRT. It might be a "mistake" that isn't a mistake after all, or it might be Monday-level misdirection.

@Barry Ancona

Third option: They don‚Äôt trust Monday solvers not to either snicker or clutch pearls at the Latin word whose literal meaning is ‚Äúwith.‚Äù

Nick,
Good thought, but the word has appeared in Monday clues ... and in the grid 40 times ... so I don't think that's the issue!

@Barry Ancona

That‚Äôs an impressive stat. Thanks, Ms. Lempel.

@Barry Ancona With stats like that, it is surely not long before ‚ÄúLempel‚Äù becomes an entry in its own right, a Natick admittedly, in an NYT crossword? I shall look out for a clue along the lines of ‚ÄúSetter with a 1979 debut‚Äù

(I am assuming - perhaps wrongly - that Ms Lempel‚Äôs record is unusually long. Maybe there is a  greater Methuselah out there?)
@Barry Ancona you can tell.  Perfectly pleasant Monday in my opinion

@dutchiris

I don't mean that the answers don't seem fresh, I mean that I remember working the puzzle, and not that long ago.  Of course, that's the essence of deja vu, but I didn't have to read a lot of the clues to know what the fill was going to be.
@Anita, I should have read your post before writing mine, which seems very FLAT in comparison. Well done!

@john,
To the contrary, yours is much better! I laughed out loud at Sioux the airline.

@john ezra

Ah, truer words . . . if only my frontal lobes would ignore those wild hairs. A tug of the forelock to your self contol, and another delightful observation  from E.D. -

I'm Nobody! Who are you? 
Are you ‚Äî Nobody ‚Äî too? 
Then there's a pair of us! 
Don't tell! they'd advertise ‚Äî you know! 

How dreary ‚Äî to be ‚Äî Somebody! 
How public ‚Äî like a Frog ‚Äî 
To tell your name ‚Äî the livelong June ‚Äî 
To an admiring Bog!
@R - It's a Monday puzzle.  It's supposed to be easy for experienced puzzlers, and a nice break from the end-of-the-week tortures.
@R you can always try solving with just the across clues...
@RozzieGrandma I've had less success with that because the theme answers are hidden

@Whoa Nellie

One, according to Remind Magazine‚Äôs website:

‚ÄúThe Case of the Deadly Verdict‚Äù (1963)
PERRY MASON, Raymond Burr (left), 1957-66
Everett Collection [photo omitted]

In this humdinger of a Season 7 episode, Perry unsuccessfully defends beautiful Janice Barton (Julie Adams), whose loved ones seem to suffer mysterious tragedies. Barton was convicted of the poisoning death of her aunt and lies to Mason on the stand, to boot. She is sentenced to death.

Over time, Perry discovers that poor Aunt Amanda was actually the victim of a botched prescription, which Janice unsuspectingly gave her. But by the time Perry and his team learn the truth, Barton is out of appeals and headed for the gas chamber.


The verdict: Though Perry knows something is amiss, he is both unable to convince his client to tell the truth, and legally unable to save her life when he figures it out himself.
@Strudel Dad AHA! Thanks for that! https://youtu.be/PA9t1nSGXXE?si=buqLmU5wzm0I8NRO
@Joe me too! GO US

@Joe P
It was my fastest solve, also!  A good start to the week!
@Whoa Nellie - Greetings from Bill Danoff.  Puzzle was an evening delight.
@Whoa Nellie Wow can‚Äôt believe you did that. I was like ‚Äúomg is this‚Ä¶?‚Äù I tried it on the piano and I couldn‚Äôt get it to TAKE OFF but I think I like it.

@Steve L

Yea, it would be interesting to know how fast I would have been if I redid it on my laptop. I'm about half and half between phone and laptop. 

My 8th grade typing teacher was Mr. Welch, who I am quite certain is also no longer with us. I think of him often though. He was a bit of an odd duck in his manner, and a lot of the students laughed at him behind his back‚Äîsometimes in front of....  It was upsetting. 

He was a good guy and a veteran. I never understood their mockery. I guess other than kids can sure be cruel. I mean, so what if he was a bit monotone and robotic in manner, if you needed help he was there‚Äîalways patient and always kind.

@Steve L
dont see what all the fuss is about "touch typing."
we all have two index fingers just for that very purpose.
didnt even need anyone to teach me.

@Matt
Often called the ‚ÄúHunt & Peck‚Äù system.

@Steve L
I'm surprised to hear that touch-typing would make much difference. Adding letters to squares is such a choppy business: a few letters, tab to next word, a few more letters, tab, etc. And you need to keep your eyes on the screen (at least I do) to make sure you don't double up or skip letters by accident because of crosses. I don't see how you'd get any smooth progress going.

@HeathieJ

well, now that you mention it, we do also have two nostrils‚Ä¶

@Strudel Dad
I remember "Hunt & Peck", great store in NYC in the West 40s. Specialized in small luxury goods like fur stoles and feather-trimmed cloches. Long since swept aside by an influx of secret PETA shoppers who staged repeat surprise demos, smuggling stoats and bats in under their coats and hats.
Typing lessons? At school? Yet another thing that's different in our countries. Nobody taught me to type at school. My parents took care of it themselves.

@Andrzej

We did not own a typewriter of any sort. My parents would not have been capable of teaching us.

@HeathieJ

My parents were scholars who published regularly. We had two typewriters. The school had none (that I ever saw).

@Strudel Dad

When I was an undergraduate I worked as a copy boy in the local news room.

One of the reporters typed purely Hunt and Peck.  But he was *blazing* fast, much faster than I was with my standard technique.

That would have been bad enough, but he was also deadly accurate.  I'd see two or three page stories go out without a single typo.

It was just phenomenal.

@Francis
I have to believe that most of the commentary challenging, or at least being sceptical of, the merits of touch-typing are being made either: (i) tongue-in-cheek; or (ii) by persons who are too young to remember manual typewriters.  I taught myself touch-typing ‚Äî J, J, J, space, K,K,K space ‚Äî when I was about 11 years old, using a manual that my sister brought home from a typing school course she was taking.  It was one of the most valuable skills I ever developed, making it possible to produce documents in the computer age without needing an intermediary to transcribe dictation.  I suppose that anyone who grew up in the BlackBerry era, or a few years later in the iPhone era, would look upon these comments with bemusement.
@HeathieJ it took me 12 minutes on my phone. And yes, I had to think about some answers... imagining experienced solvers that do a saturday in 5 minutes in horror at that notion lol.

@Andrzej

So many memories in this thread! I didn't have room in my schedule for typing so I took an adult ed course, one night a week, about a half hour drive from my home. I didn't have my drivers license yet, so my parents drove me. I took the class with a friend, and I think we were the youngest people there, at about 15. We used manual typewriters too.

I am old enough to have typed my college papers on a manual typewriter as well. My mother's, from her college days. I still have it. Somewhere.

My dad -- who never took a formal course -- was the king of two-finger typing, but he used his left index finger exclusively for the space bar, and his right index finger for everything else. He was pretty fast, and wrote a lot of short stories and even tried a novel or two.

@HeathieJ

And, like you, it takes me more than 5 minutes to re-enter the answers.

Hats off to those who can do it faster, but I never expect (nor particularly desire) to become one of them.

@Steve L
Of course, that is true -- for ordinary typjng.
But filling in a crossword grid is a peculiar activity. You can't assume that the receiving page is blank; instead it is full of obstacles -- black squares, previously filled white squares, even fancy work like rebuses. This means you can't focus completely on the source materials as you can when typing onto a blank.page.
One of my earliest summer jobs was working in an accountant's office using an electric typewriter. Many pages consisted of tables, columns, and lists of figures. I was a good typist, speedy and accurate in producing letters, but those tables slowed me to a crawl. What with realigning columns from line to line, aligning decimal points within columns, and maintaining table borders, two or three tables might take me over an hour, sometimes closer to two. That would be closer to filling in an online crossword grid.
The 11/5/1996 NYT Crossword was spectacular, but it did not have HAITI as an entry (with any clue). Try again.
N.B. HAITI has never been clued in the NYT XWP as Port-au-Prince's island. It has been clued a number of times as Port-au-Prince's land.

@Autumn

Germany and the Germans are called Niemcy in Polish (and other Slavic languages). "Niemy" means "mute". When my ancestors encountered the ancestors of Germans over a thousand years ago, they couldn't understand them, unlike their Slavic neighbors. Thus, they considered them effectively mute - unable to speak, at least understandably. In turn, Slavs are called S≈Çowianie. "S≈Çowo".means "word". S≈Çowianin is literally one who has mastered "the word" - that is one who can speak.

@Autumn

This is really interesting, thank you. I‚Äôve spent some time reading up on this, however (peer-reviewed literature, not Wikipedia etc.) and, while Crazy Horse was certainly Lakota, a couple of thoughts on your post: (1) The Lakota people are a subgroup of what we call the Sioux, so referring to the broader term in the clue is not incorrect (I‚Äôm looking at this from a linguistic perspective‚Äîforgive me if there are others that would counteract this); (2) the claim that the French (if I may jingoistically point out here that it *was* the French and not we who arrived at the name*‚Ä¶) called the Ojibwe people and language ‚ÄòSioux‚Äô or ‚Äòthe enemy‚Äô based on an Iroquois term for them belongs in folk etymology. There are other theories, and theories they will remain‚Äîincluding the one you‚Äôve cited‚Äîas something as abbreviated as the monosyllabic /Ààs√º/, with its etymological history mostly oral, based on centuries-old accounts by settlers who were not linguistic scholars, will never be sufficiently attested. 

Modern English and its speakers certainly don‚Äôt think of the Sioux as ‚Äòthe enemy.‚Äô As @Andrzej and @ŒôŒ±œÉœâŒΩ point out, many demonyms stem from less-than favorable impressions of first contact, yet they persist. After centuries, they no longer retain the initial taste of misunderstanding or conflict (no one thinks of the Berbers as barbaric, the Poles don‚Äôt think Germans are mute). 

The clue may be broad for Crazy Horse‚Äôs people, but it‚Äôs not meant to insult. 

*[smile]
